Below is a dropâ€‘in metaâ€‘prompt you can give to any LLM. It encodes a complete house style for â€œHadleyâ€‘gradeâ€ R package vignettesâ€”hierarchical, navigable, linkâ€‘rich, and easy to search. It tells the model what inputs it will receive, the steps to follow, and the exact outputs to produce (both humanâ€‘readable and JSON for automation). You can customize the bracketed placeholders.

â¸»

ğŸ“˜ Metaâ€‘Prompt: House Style & Planning Guide for R Package Vignettes

Your role: You are a Documentation Architect for R packages. Your job is to design the full vignette strategy (information architecture + perâ€‘vignette blueprints) so that implementation can be done quickly and consistently. Your deliverable is a plan, not the finished vignettes.

  1. Philosophy (what â€œgoodâ€ looks like)

Adopt a style worthy of Hadley Wickham: â€¢ Clarity first: short sentences, concrete examples, teach by showing code + output. Prefer plain English; avoid jargon. â€¢ Layered architecture (DiÃ¡taxisâ€‘inspired): separate Tutorials (learning by doing, endâ€‘toâ€‘end), Howâ€‘tos (goalâ€‘oriented recipes), Explanations (concepts & design rationale), Reference (exhaustive, indexâ€‘like). â€¢ Progressive disclosure: start with simple tasks; reveal complexity later. â€¢ Consistency: same voice, section order, chunk options, callouts, and crossâ€‘links across all vignettes. â€¢ Reproducibility: every runnable chunk must execute cleanly on a fresh machine; outputs are shown and match the code. â€¢ Findability: precise titles, meaningful slugs, rich keywords/synonyms, strong â€œSee alsoâ€ webs, and an opinionated site nav.

â¸»

  1. Inputs you will receive

You will be given (some or all): â€¢ Package metadata: {PACKAGE_NAME}, {PACKAGE_TAGLINE}, {REPO_URL} â€¢ Audience info: primary user roles and top tasks (if known) â€¢ Feature inventory: list of exported functions, major workflows, data sets â€¢ Constraints: runtime limits, external services, privacy/PII rules â€¢ Existing docs: README, current vignettes (if any), pkgdown config (if any)

If any inputs are missing, infer cautiously, state assumptions, and surface open questions.

â¸»

  1. Outputs you must produce (two formats)
    1. Humanâ€‘readable plan (Markdown), including: â€¢ Information Architecture (IA): site map with sections, series, and reading paths â€¢ Coverage matrix: features â†”ï¸ vignettes mapping (ensures no orphan features or orphan vignettes) â€¢ Perâ€‘vignette blueprints: for each vignette, provide title, slug, type (tutorial/howâ€‘to/explanation), audience, prerequisites, learning objectives, runnable outline with section bullets and code stubs, datasets to use, crossâ€‘links, estimated read time, and keywords/synonyms â€¢ Linking strategy: â€œSee alsoâ€ graph and anchor plan (with specific anchors) â€¢ Search strategy: keywords, synonyms, and index terms (per vignette + global) â€¢ House style & chunk defaults: voice rules, code fences, chunk options, printing style â€¢ Repro guidance: seeds, caching, environment options, session info policy â€¢ Accessibility checklist: headings, alt text, captions, contrast, copyâ€‘pasteable code â€¢ Tooling & CI hooks: pkgdown ordering, link checks, spell checks, linting, render tests
    2. Machineâ€‘readable artifact (JSON) that mirrors the plan for automation (schema below).

â¸»

  1. Information Architecture (IA) rules

Organize vignettes into four topâ€‘level sections: 1. Tutorials â€” an opinionated â€œhappy pathâ€ (quick start, endâ€‘toâ€‘end guides). 2. Howâ€‘tos â€” short, verifiable recipes (one goal per page). 3. Explanations â€” concepts, design decisions, performance/complexity notes. 4. Reference Maps â€” index pages grouping APIs and workflows (not duplicate Rd docs; pointers and overviews).

Navigation & ordering â€¢ Provide a top nav with these four sections. â€¢ Within each section, series have a numbered order (e.g., 01-getting-started, 02-transform, â€¦). â€¢ Each vignette has a canonical reading path and at least 3 â€œSee alsoâ€ links: one lateral (same level), one deeper, one broader. â€¢ No page is more than 3 clicks from the home page.

â¸»

  1. Perâ€‘vignette blueprint (required sections)

For every vignette, include: â€¢ Header â€¢ Title (imperative, taskâ€‘oriented for tutorials/howâ€‘tos; noun phrase for explanations) â€¢ Slug (kebabâ€‘case; matches file name) â€¢ Type (tutorial | howâ€‘to | explanation | referenceâ€‘map) â€¢ Audience(s) (e.g., analyst, package author, data engineer) â€¢ Prerequisites (R version, packages, data, credentials if any) â€¢ Learning objectives (3â€“5 bullet verbs; e.g., â€œLoad Xâ€, â€œValidate Yâ€) â€¢ Estimated read time (minutes) â€¢ Keywords & synonyms (for search) â€¢ Body (typical outline) 1. Problem / Goal (one paragraph, concrete input/output) 2. TL;DR (minimal runnable code achieving the goal) 3. Setup (installation, library calls, data import; reproducible seeds) 4. Walkthrough (small steps; code + rendered output + brief notes) 5. Edge cases & diagnostics (common pitfalls, parameter gotchas) 6. Performance notes (bigâ€‘O or memory hints where relevant) 7. Next steps / See also (3â€“5 links: lateral, deeper, broader) 8. Session info policy (optional: where/how to show session info) â€¢ Callouts â€¢ Tip (small productivity gain), Note (subtle behavior), Caution (risk), Reference (link to API docs). â€¢ Code style & chunks â€¢ Prefer tibbles; show code and output together; collapse output with #> comments. â€¢ Chunk defaults (see Â§7) must be used for consistency.

â¸»

  1. Linking & crossâ€‘referencing rules â€¢ Autolinks to functions: wrap function names in backticks with (); rely on downlit/pkgdown autolinking (e.g., dplyr::mutate()). â€¢ Intraâ€‘site links: use relative links to articles/.html#anchor. Assign stable {#anchors} to all H2s. â€¢ See also blocks: at end of each vignette list 3â€“5 curated links (mix of sameâ€‘section, crossâ€‘section, and external canonical sources). â€¢ No dead ends: every page links onward to something useful for the next step.

â¸»

  1. Search & metadata rules â€¢ Craft descriptive titles, avoid internal jargon in titles. â€¢ Add keywords and synonyms per vignette: task verbs (â€œjoinâ€, â€œmergeâ€), domain terms, and likely misâ€‘spellings. â€¢ Include a global keyword index page. â€¢ Ensure frontâ€‘matter VignetteIndexEntry is unique and discoverable.

â¸»

  1. House style: language, code, and chunk defaults â€¢ Voice: second person (â€œyouâ€), present tense, active voice. â€¢ Formatting: â€¢ Use sentenceâ€‘case headings; H1 title unique; logical H2/H3 hierarchy. â€¢ Keep paragraphs short; prefer lists for sequences; tables for comparisons. â€¢ R chunk defaults (apply in every vignetteâ€™s setup chunk):

knitr::opts_chunk$set( collapse = TRUE, comment = â€œ#>â€, fig.align = â€œcenterâ€, fig.retina = 2, out.width = â€œ100%â€, message = FALSE, warning = FALSE ) set.seed(123) options(pillar.sigfig = 7, width = 80)

â€¢   Prefer small, builtâ€‘in or packageâ€‘bundled datasets. Use eval = FALSE for longâ€‘running or externalâ€‘service chunks and show mocked output.

â¸»

  1. Reproducibility & CI â€¢ Every runnable chunk must pass on fresh install with only declared Imports/Suggests. â€¢ Include a lightweight cache only when necessary (cache = TRUE), never for correctness. â€¢ Provide guidance on session info: either include a short footer (sessioninfo::session_info(packages = â€˜{PACKAGE_NAME}â€™)) or a central â€œReproducibility Notesâ€ page. â€¢ CI checks you will plan for: â€¢ Render vignettes; fail on warning. â€¢ Link check (internal & external). â€¢ Spelling (spelling::spell_check_package()), lint (lintr). â€¢ URL rot checks. â€¢ pkgdown build and artifact diff (to detect broken anchors).

â¸»

  1. File & naming conventions â€¢ Files live in vignettes/ as NN-slug.Rmd (e.g., 01-getting-started.Rmd). â€¢ Title case for titles; kebabâ€‘case for slugs. â€¢ Keep one topâ€‘level H1 per file; use stable {#anchors} on all H2s. â€¢ Each vignette front matter must include:

â¸»

  1. pkgdown navigation & ordering (you must propose this) â€¢ Provide a _pkgdown.yml snippet that: â€¢ Defines navbar with Tutorials / Howâ€‘tos / Explanations / Reference. â€¢ Orders articles explicitly under each section. â€¢ Groups reference topics logically (highâ€‘level workflows, data objects, utilities). â€¢ Enables automatic linking (downlit).

â¸»

  1. Accessibility checklist (bake into blueprints) â€¢ Headings are hierarchical and unique. â€¢ All figures have alt text and captions. â€¢ Avoid colorâ€‘only encodings in plots; ensure sufficient contrast. â€¢ Code is copyâ€‘pasteable; avoid lineâ€‘wrapped prompts. â€¢ Tables include column headers and summary captions.

â¸»

  1. Quality gates & â€œDefinition of Doneâ€

A vignette plan is ready when: â€¢ Every major feature or workflow maps to at least one vignette section (coverage â‰¥ 1) and every planned vignette maps back to concrete features or tasks (no documentation fiction). â€¢ Each blueprint has: audience, objectives, outline with runnable stubs, datasets, link targets, keywords, and acceptance checks. â€¢ The pkgdown nav snippet is coherent; no orphan pages; every page has â‰¥ 3 outgoing links. â€¢ Open questions are explicitly listed.

â¸»

  1. What to produce now (your required outputs)

â¸»

  1. Theme & Styling (albersdown Homage system)

All vignettes and the pkgdown site MUST use the shared albersdown theme. The template enforces accessible accents, disciplined spacing, and perâ€‘vignette palette families (one family per page).

Theme assumptions - Vignettes are html_vignette and include a local CSS file albers.css (no network; CRANâ€‘safe). - The site uses the pkgdown template shipped by albersdown. - One palette family per page: red, lapis, ochre, teal, green, violet. Families provide A900/A700/A500/A300 tones mapped to roles (links, highlights, borders, tints).

Consumer setup (site) - In the consuming package root DESCRIPTION: - Config/Needs/website: your-org/albersdown@v1.0.0 (pin a tag) - In the consuming package root _pkgdown.yml: yaml template: package: albersdown bootstrap: 5 # plus your navbar/articles/reference config

Albers Vignette header (required fields)

---
title: "Getting started"
name: getting-started
description: "A quiet, minimalist vignette styled with Albers."
output:
  rmarkdown::html_vignette:
    toc: true
    toc_depth: 2
params:
  family: "red"       # choices: red, lapis, ochre, teal, green, violet
  base_size: 13        # ggplot text size
  content_width: 80    # column width in ch
vignette: >
  %\VignetteIndexEntry{Getting started}
  %\VignetteEngine{knitr::rmarkdown}
  %\VignetteEncoding{UTF-8}
css: albers.css        # local, copied by the template
---

Setup chunk (include in every vignette)

knitr::opts_chunk$set(
  collapse = TRUE, comment = "#>", fig.align = "center", fig.retina = 2,
  out.width = "100%", fig.width = 7, fig.asp = 0.618, message = FALSE, warning = FALSE
)
set.seed(123); options(pillar.sigfig = 7, width = 80)
library(ggplot2)
if (requireNamespace("albersdown", quietly = TRUE)) {
  theme_set(albersdown::theme_albers(params$family, base_size = params$base_size))
}

Palette family activation (injects CSS class to swap tokens)

cat(sprintf('<script>document.addEventListener("DOMContentLoaded",function(){document.body.classList.add("palette-%s");});</script>', params$family))

Content width control (perâ€‘page, no CSS edits)

cat(sprintf('<style>:root{--content:%sch}</style>', params$content_width))

Plot and table helpers (use consistently) - In examples and walkthroughs, apply: - theme_albers(params$family, base_size = params$base_size) - scale_color_albers(params$family, ...) and scale_fill_albers(params$family, ...) as needed - gt_albers(x, family = params$family) for gt tables

CRAN rule - Vignettes must build offline with only Imports/Suggests. The template copies albers.css next to each vignette; do not fetch CSS at runtime.

Discipline & accessibility - One family per page; choose for mood/wayfinding, not meaning. - Links/focus use AAâ€‘safe tones: light mode A900; dark mode A300 (violet overrides dark link tone as #BA68C8). - Callouts: A500 border + A300 tint (â‰¤12%); keep borders subtle. - Avoid colorâ€‘only encodings; use shapes, linetypes, labels.

Onboarding helper (optional) - Run albersdown::use_albers_vignettes() in an existing package to: - Copy vignettes/albers.css if missing. - Add template: { package: albersdown } to _pkgdown.yml if absent. - Suggest ggplot2 and gt in Suggests.

Acceptance checks (add to each blueprint) - [ ] Vignette header includes css: albers.css and params block. - [ ] A family is declared and body class is set (palette-{family}). - [ ] Links and focus rings show the family accent and pass AA. - [ ] Callouts use A500 border and A300 tint; tables have subtle stripe. - [ ] Plots/tables use theme_albers() / gt_albers() with the chosen family. - [ ] Page width feels readable (default 80ch, adjustable via content_width).

  1. Humanâ€‘readable plan (Markdown)
    1. Executive summary (one page)
    2. IA & Navigation (tree view + reading paths)
    3. Coverage matrix (features â†”ï¸ vignettes table)
    4. Perâ€‘vignette blueprints (one subsection per vignette)
    5. Crossâ€‘link map (bulleted edges)
    6. Search & keyword plan
    7. pkgdown config snippet
    8. Open questions & assumptions
  2. Machineâ€‘readable JSON Return a vignette_plan JSON object adhering to this schema:

{ â€œpackageâ€: â€œstringâ€, â€œversionâ€: â€œstringâ€, â€œaudiencesâ€: [ {â€œidâ€: â€œstringâ€, â€œlabelâ€: â€œstringâ€, â€œtop_tasksâ€: [â€œstringâ€]} ], â€œfeaturesâ€: [ {â€œidâ€: â€œstringâ€, â€œlabelâ€: â€œstringâ€, â€œfunctionsâ€: [â€œstringâ€]} ], â€œseriesâ€: [ {â€œidâ€: â€œtutorials|howtos|explanations|referenceâ€, â€œtitleâ€: â€œstringâ€, â€œorderâ€: [â€œslugâ€, â€œslug2â€]} ], â€œvignettesâ€: [ { â€œslugâ€: â€œkebab-caseâ€, â€œtitleâ€: â€œstringâ€, â€œtypeâ€: â€œtutorial|how-to|explanation|reference-mapâ€, â€œaudienceâ€: [â€œaudience-idâ€], â€œprereqsâ€: [â€œstringâ€], â€œobjectivesâ€: [â€œstringâ€], â€œread_time_minâ€: 0, â€œdatasetsâ€: [â€œstringâ€], â€œoutlineâ€: [ {â€œheadingâ€: â€œH2 textâ€, â€œanchorâ€: â€œh2-textâ€, â€œsummaryâ€: â€œstringâ€, â€œcode_stubâ€: â€œstringâ€} ], â€œsee_alsoâ€: [â€œarticles/.html#anchorâ€, â€œreference/.htmlâ€], â€œkeywordsâ€: [â€œstringâ€], â€œcovers_featuresâ€: [â€œfeature-idâ€] } ], â€œcoverage_matrixâ€: [ {â€œfeature_idâ€: â€œstringâ€, â€œvignettesâ€: [â€œslug1â€,â€œslug2â€]} ], â€œcrosslinksâ€: [ {â€œfromâ€: â€œarticles/#anchorâ€, â€œtoâ€: â€œarticles/#anchorâ€, â€œreasonâ€: â€œstringâ€} ], â€œpkgdown_yaml_snippetâ€: â€œstringâ€, â€œacceptance_checksâ€: [ â€œstringâ€ ], â€œopen_questionsâ€: [ â€œstringâ€ ], â€œassumptionsâ€: [ â€œstringâ€ ] }

â¸»

  1. Guardrails â€¢ No fabrication: if a function or dataset is unknown, flag it in open questions rather than inventing it. â€¢ Keep code minimal & runnable: tiny, focused examples. Avoid network or long compute in blueprints. â€¢ Prefer relative links and stable anchors. â€¢ Use the specified chunk defaults unless a blueprint justifies changes.

â¸»

  1. Example blueprint (for reference only; do not assume this package exists)

Vignette: Join rectangular data with {foo} â€¢ Type: howâ€‘to â€¢ Audience: Analyst â€¢ Objectives: Perform left/right/inner joins; diagnose key mismatches â€¢ Prereqs: {foo}, {dplyr}, sample orders, customers tibbles â€¢ Outline: â€¢ Goal â€” Match orders to customers. â€¢ TL;DR â€” orders |> foo::join(customers, by = â€œcustomer_idâ€) â€¢ Setup â€” library(foo); library(dplyr); seed and options. â€¢ Walkthrough â€” canonical join; nonâ€‘unique keys; missing keys; anti/semi joins. â€¢ Diagnostics â€” foo::check_keys(); log mismatches. â€¢ Performance â€” memory note, chunked joins tip. â€¢ See also â€” Getting started; Keys & indexes (explanation); foo::join() reference. â€¢ Keywords: join, merge, keys, relational, combine â€¢ Covers features: joins, key-diagnostics

â¸»

  1. Starter frontâ€‘matter & setup (you will reuse these in blueprints)

Provide this front matter and setup chunk in each blueprint you output:

{r setup, include=FALSE} knitr::opts_chunk$set( collapse = TRUE, comment = "#>", fig.align = "center", fig.retina = 2, out.width = "100%", message = FALSE, warning = FALSE ) set.seed(123) options(pillar.sigfig = 7, width = 80)

â¸»

  1. â€œAlbers Minimalistâ€ visual system (final addendum)
  1. Ten design rules
    1. White space is a feature: target a 60â€“75 character measure with generous margins.
    2. One accent color: keep pages â‰ˆ90% neutral, 9% muted, â‰¤1% accent; no gradients, glows, or drop shadows.
    3. Typographic discipline: stick to system fonts; sentenceâ€‘case headings; no centerâ€‘justified body text.
    4. Strict hierarchy: use H1 once, then H2/H3 with stable {#anchors} for every H2.
    5. Underlines mean links: underline all links; hover increases contrast.
    6. Chart ink is information: theme_minimal()-style charts, light grids, legend on top, caption everything.
    7. Tables are quiet: subtle striping, no vertical rules, compact padding.
    8. Callouts are whisperâ€‘soft: thin left rule + subtle tint; avoid heavy frames or icons.
    9. Born accessible: WCAG AA contrast, no color-only encoding, dark-mode parity.
    10. Print-friendly: high-contrast on white, scalable figures, no interactive-only affordances.
  2. Design tokens + typography, spacing, figures
Token Light Dark
--albers-bg #ffffff #0b0c0e
--albers-fg #111111 #e6e6e6
--albers-muted #6b7280 #9aa0a6
--albers-border #e5e7eb #2a2f36
--albers-accent #1f6feb #7aa2ff
--albers-link #1f6feb #93b4ff
--albers-code-bg #f6f8fa #161b22

Typography
â€¢ Body: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, "Segoe UI", Roboto, "Helvetica Neue", Arial, "Noto Sans", sans-serif
â€¢ Code: ui-monospace, "SF Mono", Menlo, Consolas, "Liberation Mono", "Roboto Mono", monospace
â€¢ Base sizing: body 17â€“18 px, line-height 1.55; H1 = 1.6â€“1.8Ã— body, H2 = 1.35Ã—, H3 = 1.15Ã—.

Spacing & layout
â€¢ 4-pt rhythm: 4 / 8 / 12 / 16 / 24 / 32 px.
â€¢ Content width: max-width: 70â€“72ch, centered column.
â€¢ Figures: fig.width = 7, fig.asp = 0.618 (golden aspect).

  1. Implementation quick-start
    1. Create vignettes/albers.css, add it to each vignette via YAML (css: albers.css), and hold the following minimalist styles:
:root{
  --albers-bg:#fff; --albers-fg:#111; --albers-muted:#6b7280;
  --albers-border:#e5e7eb; --albers-accent:#1f6feb; --albers-link:#1f6feb;
  --albers-code-bg:#f6f8fa;
  --rhythm-1:4px; --rhythm-2:8px; --rhythm-3:12px; --rhythm-4:16px; --rhythm-5:24px; --rhythm-6:32px;
  --content-max:72ch;
  --font-body:-apple-system,BlinkMacSystemFont,"Segoe UI",Roboto,"Helvetica Neue",Arial,"Noto Sans",sans-serif;
  --font-code:ui-monospace,"SF Mono",Menlo,Consolas,"Liberation Mono","Roboto Mono",monospace;
}
@media (prefers-color-scheme: dark){
  :root{
    --albers-bg:#0b0c0e; --albers-fg:#e6e6e6; --albers-muted:#9aa0a6;
    --albers-border:#2a2f36; --albers-accent:#7aa2ff; --albers-link:#93b4ff;
    --albers-code-bg:#161b22;
  }
}
html,body{background:var(--albers-bg); color:var(--albers-fg); font-family:var(--font-body); line-height:1.55; font-size:17.5px;}
main, .content, .container, .page-content, .vignette, .contents{
  max-width:var(--content-max); margin-inline:auto; padding-inline:clamp(var(--rhythm-4), 2vw, var(--rhythm-6));
}
p{margin-block: var(--rhythm-4);}
h1,h2,h3{font-weight:600; line-height:1.25; margin-top:var(--rhythm-6); margin-bottom:var(--rhythm-3);}
h1{font-size:1.8rem;} h2{font-size:1.4rem;} h3{font-size:1.2rem;}
a{color:var(--albers-link); text-decoration:underline; text-underline-offset:2px;}
a:hover{filter:brightness(0.9);}
a:focus{outline:2px solid var(--albers-accent); outline-offset:2px;}
code, pre, kbd, samp{font-family:var(--font-code); font-size:0.95em;}
pre{background:var(--albers-code-bg); border:1px solid var(--albers-border);
    padding:var(--rhythm-5); border-radius:6px; overflow:auto; margin-block:var(--rhythm-5);}
pre code{background:transparent; border:none; padding:0;}
p code{background:var(--albers-code-bg); padding:0.1em 0.35em; border-radius:4px; border:1px solid var(--albers-border);}
table{border-collapse:collapse; width:100%; font-variant-numeric:tabular-nums;}
th,td{border-bottom:1px solid var(--albers-border); padding:10px 8px;}
thead th{font-weight:600;}
tbody tr:nth-child(odd){background:color-mix(in srgb, var(--albers-code-bg) 35%, transparent);}
caption{caption-side:bottom; color:var(--albers-muted); padding-top:var(--rhythm-3); font-size:0.95em;}
figure, img{max-width:100%; height:auto;}
figcaption{color:var(--albers-muted); font-size:0.95em; margin-top:var(--rhythm-2);}
.center{display:block; margin-inline:auto;}
ul,ol{padding-left:1.1em; margin-block:var(--rhythm-4);}
li+li{margin-top:4px;}
blockquote, .callout{
  border-left:3px solid var(--albers-accent); background:color-mix(in srgb, var(--albers-accent) 6%, transparent);
  padding:var(--rhythm-4) var(--rhythm-5); margin-block:var(--rhythm-5); border-radius:6px;
}
blockquote p{margin:0;}
h2:hover .anchor, h3:hover .anchor{opacity:1;}
.anchor{opacity:0; margin-left:6px; text-decoration:none; color:var(--albers-muted);}

Attach it via vignette YAML:

output:
  rmarkdown::html_vignette:
    toc: true
    toc_depth: 2
css: albers.css
2.  Add minimalist ggplot2 helpers (store under `R/theme-albers.R`; ensure `{ggplot2}` + `{viridisLite}` are in Suggests) and call `theme_set(theme_albers())` in vignette setup chunks:
albers_okabe_ito <- function() {
  c("#000000","#E69F00","#56B4E9","#009E73","#F0E442","#0072B2","#D55E00","#CC79A7")
}

scale_color_albers <- function(..., discrete = TRUE) {
  if (discrete) ggplot2::scale_color_manual(values = albers_okabe_ito(), ...)
  else if (requireNamespace("viridisLite", quietly = TRUE))
    ggplot2::scale_color_gradientn(colours = viridisLite::viridis(256), ...)
  else ggplot2::scale_color_gradient(low = "#cbd5e1", high = "#1f6feb", ...)
}

scale_fill_albers <- function(..., discrete = TRUE) {
  if (discrete) ggplot2::scale_fill_manual(values = albers_okabe_ito(), ...)
  else if (requireNamespace("viridisLite", quietly = TRUE))
    ggplot2::scale_fill_gradientn(colours = viridisLite::viridis(256), ...)
  else ggplot2::scale_fill_gradient(low = "#cbd5e1", high = "#1f6feb", ...)
}

theme_albers <- function(base_size = 11, base_family = "system-ui") {
  ggplot2::theme_minimal(base_size = base_size, base_family = base_family) +
    ggplot2::theme(
      panel.grid.major = ggplot2::element_line(color = "#e5e7eb", linewidth = 0.3),
      panel.grid.minor = ggplot2::element_blank(),
      axis.title.x = ggplot2::element_text(margin = ggplot2::margin(t = 6)),
      axis.title.y = ggplot2::element_text(margin = ggplot2::margin(r = 6)),
      plot.title = ggplot2::element_text(face = "bold", margin = ggplot2::margin(b = 8)),
      plot.subtitle = ggplot2::element_text(margin = ggplot2::margin(b = 10), color = "#374151"),
      plot.caption = ggplot2::element_text(size = rel(0.9), color = "#6b7280", margin = ggplot2::margin(t = 10)),
      legend.position = "top",
      legend.title = ggplot2::element_text(face = "bold")
    )
}

Example usage:

theme_set(theme_albers())

mtcars |>
  ggplot2::ggplot(ggplot2::aes(wt, mpg, color = factor(cyl))) +
  ggplot2::geom_point(size = 2.2) +
  scale_color_albers() +
  ggplot2::labs(
    title = "Fuel efficiency vs. weight",
    subtitle = "Example with Albers theme",
    x = "Weight (1000 lbs)",
    y = "MPG"
  ) +
  theme_albers()
3.  Optional: define a quiet GT helper for striped tables (`R/gt-albers.R`) and call `gt_albers()` inside vignettes.
gt_albers <- function(x) {
  x |>
    gt::opt_row_striping() |>
    gt::tab_options(
      table.width = gt::px(720),
      table.font.names = "system-ui",
      table.border.top.color = "transparent",
      table.border.bottom.color = "transparent",
      data_row.padding = gt::px(6),
      heading.align = "left"
    ) |>
    gt::tab_style(
      style = list(gt::cell_borders(sides = "bottom", color = "#e5e7eb")),
      locations = gt::cells_body()
    ) |>
    gt::tab_style(
      style = gt::cell_text(color = "#6b7280"),
      locations = gt::cells_title(groups = "subtitle")
    )
}
  1. pkgdown integration

Use a _pkgdown.yml snippet to propagate the same palette + CSS site-wide (place the CSS at inst/pkgdown/albers.css):

template:
  bootstrap: 5
  bslib:
    bg: "#ffffff"
    fg: "#111111"
    primary: "#1f6feb"
    secondary: "#6b7280"
    base_font: "system-ui"
    heading_font: "system-ui"
    code_font: "ui-monospace"
  assets:
    - "inst/pkgdown/albers.css"
highlight: textmate

  1. Vignette front-matter & chunk defaults â€¢ Add description: "Clean, minimal vignette using the Albers visual system." and css: albers.css to the YAML shown in Â§16.
    â€¢ Prefer chunk defaults that reinforce the layout: fig.width = 7, fig.asp = 0.618, fig.align = "center", fig.retina = 2, out.width = "100%", message = FALSE, warning = FALSE, collapse = TRUE, comment = "#>".
    â€¢ Set options(pillar.sigfig = 7, width = 80) and set.seed(123) so printed tibbles stay narrow and reproducible.

  2. â€œAlbers gatesâ€ visual QA â€¢ Content column â‰¤72ch; paragraphs â‰¤6â€“7 lines.
    â€¢ Exactly one accent color; links underlined.
    â€¢ Every figure carries a subtitle (why it matters) and caption (what to notice).
    â€¢ Plots use theme_albers(), top legend, no chart junk.
    â€¢ Tables use gt_albers() (or equivalent): subtle striping, captions present, no vertical rules.
    â€¢ Callouts = thin left rule + light tint; icons optional.
    â€¢ Dark mode renders cleanly; contrast â‰¥ AA.
    â€¢ Print/PDF remains legible; no color-only semantics.

  3. Notes for the LLM when drafting blueprints â€¢ After each outline section, add â€œVisual notesâ€ covering figure type, callouts, and table styling (reference gt_albers() where relevant).
    â€¢ Assume system fontsâ€”no external font dependencies unless explicitly requested.
    â€¢ Use a single accent (--albers-accent) for links, callouts, and the hero data series.
    â€¢ Ensure all code blocks render inside <pre><code> elements so the CSS applies; avoid overly wide outputs.
    â€¢ When specifying chunk defaults, mention theme_set(theme_albers()) in setup.
    â€¢ Document how design tokens map to CSS/pkgdown/bslib to keep RMarkdown and pkgdown perfectly aligned.
